docs.lead_paragraph: Blaming cuts in Medicare payments, Vencor Inc., a troubled nursing home chain that expanded and took on debt at the wrong time, filed for protection yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. The company, which operates 300 nursing homes and 60 hospitals, also asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., for protection for more than 100 of its units.

headline.main: Vencor Files for Bankruptcy Citing Cuts in Medicare Fees

docs.abstract: Vencor Inc, troubled nursing home chain that expanded and took on debt at wrong time, files for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws; company, which operates 300 nursing homes and 60 hospitals, also asks Federal Bankruptcy Court, for protection for more than 100 of its units; Vencor blames its financial problems on cuts in Medicare payments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is not an accident that Flo, a feisty sixty-something woman, is the star of the pharmaceutical industry's latest advertising campaign in the battle over adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare. Nor is it a coincidence that the White House held an event not long ago to focus on Medicare as a women's issue. Or that the Democratic women of the Senate formed a working group last year to examine what the various proposals to restructure Social Security would mean to women. Or that the Older Women's League, an advocacy group, issued a report on Mother's Day this year titled, ''The Face of Medicare Is a Woman You Know.''

headline.main: THE DEBATE ON AID FOR THE ELDERLY FOCUSES ON WOMEN

docs.abstract: Women become focus of debate over restructuring Medicare and Social Security; shift reflects basic demographic and political reality that they not only live longer than men, but are also more economically insecure, have more chronic health conditions and, as result, become more dependent on such basic safety net programs; defenders of safety net programs say highlighting this vulnerable population is good policy but could have potent political appeal; debate on Capitol Hill has also become bipartisan; Clinton Administration and Older Women's League contend that coverage gap is particular hardship for older women, who spend greater share of income on health care than men; Republican leaders say they will focus on needy in debating issue; drug industry's current advertising campaign features Flo, sixty-something woman who is in the two-thirds of Medicare population that has private drug coverage; plays to worries of people in group that their insurance will be replaced by less-generous and more-intrusive Government plan; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kathleen Anne Plunkett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Plunkett Jr. of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin James O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis E. O'Connor of Newington, Conn. The Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan, the president of Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown. Mrs. O'Connor, 28, graduated from Georgetown and received a master's degree in experimental methods in psychology from the University of London and a law degree from Fordham University. Until last month, she was a law clerk in New York and New Britain, Conn., for Judge Thomas J. Meskill of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Her father is the senior partner in Plunkett & Jaffe, a New York law firm that the bride is to join as an associate in October.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ellen Reilly Humphreys, a daughter of Henry J. Humphreys of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Eileen Kelly Humphreys, was married there yesterday to Edward John Dowd, a son of Margaret and Patrick Dowd, also of Bronxville. Patrick J. Ahern, a retired Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride, 28, is a financial analyst at Mutual of America, the insurance company in New York. She graduated from Salve Regina University. Her father, who retired as a vice president in the private banking division of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, is the chancellor and chief operating officer of the American Knights of Malta, a Roman Catholic charitable organization. He is also a member of the board of the American Cancer Society and the board chairman of the Terence Cardinal Cook Health Care Center in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore became the first of the current crop of Presidential contenders to lay out a detailed plan for health policy. He promised to guarantee access to affordable health insurance for all children by 2005, through a number of steps, including expansion of the 1997 Children's Health Insurance Program. Mr. Gore's plan was modest compared with President Clinton's ill-fated proposal for universal coverage. Health policy experts said the cost of Mr. Gore's plan would probably exceed $5 billion a year. ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Though rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Al Gore and Bill Bradley are both trying to restore a shamefully neglected issue to its rightful place at the forefront of public debate. The issue is health insurance -- specifically, this country's grievous failure to provide coverage for nearly one-sixth of its population. Many politicians -- and public attention -- have turned from this issue ever since President Clinton's proposal for universal health coverage crashed in 1993, a victim of political mismanagement. But the problem has not gone away, and remains a vivid and embarrassing rebuke to American democracy. As Mr. Bradley observed last week in announcing his candidacy, ''While kings and dictators come to this country for the best health care treatment in the world, you and I both know that this care is not available to the 45 million citizens who have no health insurance at all.''
docs.abstract: Editorial lauds Democratic Presidential hopefuls Bill Bradley and Vice Pres Al Gore for reviving debate on need for health insurance for rising number of uninsured Americans

docs.lead_paragraph: On a visit to East Jerusalem in July, Interior Minister Natan Sharansky announced that he wanted to end an Israeli policy that in recent years had stripped hundreds of Palestinians of their right to live in the city. ''The time has come to change this policy and to stop canceling the residence of inhabitants of East Jerusalem,'' Mr. Sharansky said. ''We cannot talk about a united Jerusalem without proper treatment of the residents of East Jerusalem. We need to do everything to insure that residents of the east receive equal treatment to those of the west.''

headline.main: Israel Relents, Letting Arab Live for Now In Jerusalem

docs.abstract: Israeli Interior Min Natan Sharansky says he wants to end Israeli policy that in recent years has stripped hundreds of Palestinians of their right to live in East Jerusalem; suspends revocation of Dr Musa Budeiri's residency; he is member of prominent Jerusalem family that has lived in city for centuries (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After staging a nine-month spree of fraudulent slip-and-fall accidents in supermarkets and convenience stores across New Jersey, Ernest Woodson, 52, of Vineland, pleaded guilty to third-degree health care fraud on Thursday, admitting that he received nearly $10,000 from nine insurance companies after faking injuries from the falls, state officials said. Edward Neafsey, the State Insurance Fraud Prosecutor, said Mr. Woodson staged 21 separate slip-and-fall accidents before his arrest in April. He would pretend to trip on anything from fallen produce to wet spots on the floor and would claim injuries ranging from broken teeth to a sore arm, Mr. Neafsey said.

headline.main: Man Admits to Fraud In Series of Phony Falls

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a pediatrician whose patients are predominantly children from low-income families, I applaud Vice President Gore's proposal to guarantee health insurance for all children by 2005 by raising the income limit for participation in the Children's Health Insurance Program (front page, Sept. 8).
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Lee M Sanders says major barrier to health insurance for many immigrant children in United States is not the income requirement, but the law, which denies coverage even to some legal immigrants (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans introduced a comprehensive bill today to regulate health maintenance organizations and to protect patients, who would gain carefully circumscribed new rights to sue health plans for injuries caused by the insurer's negligence. The full House is expected to vote soon on the measure, drafted at the request of House Republican leaders including the Speaker, J. Dennis Hastert. Given the divisive history of the issue in the House, Republican and Democratic leaders were reluctant to predict the vote.

headline.main: House Bill Would Slightly Ease Lawsuits Against H.M.O.'s
